content.raw:
Well just form a user point, when i feel like that i want to edit a model 'or edit anything' , the first thing i look at is the edit menu.

We can leave it as Edit ->"Model" and write beside it "Open Model editor" or "Enter Model editor" with a font like the one the shortcuts are written in, that way we don't have to put it in the window menu even if its entirely different windows.
content.html:
Well just form a user point, when i feel like that i want to edit a model 'or edit anything' , the first thing i look at is the edit menu.

We can leave it as Edit ->"Model" and write beside it "Open Model editor" or "Enter Model editor" with a font like the one the shortcuts are written in, that way we don't have to put it in the window menu even if its entirely different windows.

pullrequest.title: undo redo added to edit menu and re arranged it

content.raw:
Thanks. 

I'm torn. Edit does seem like a good place for edits that will directly impact the render window. On the one hand, editing a model impacts the render window. On the other hand, the process for editing the model is far more complex, and in a different mode, when compared to simply Undo-ing.  

I could see the Model and Terrain Editors being similar enough to Plotting (because they are entirely separate windows) that they go under Window.
content.html:
Thanks.

I'm torn. Edit does seem like a good place for edits that will directly impact the render window. On the one hand, editing a model impacts the render window. On the other hand, the process for editing the model is far more complex, and in a different mode, when compared to simply Undo-ing.

I could see the Model and Terrain Editors being similar enough to Plotting (because they are entirely separate windows) that they go under Window.

content.raw:
I believe we should leave the menu options in their current location. 

My suggestion stems only from what I expect as menu options, and I may not be the best source of info. Take a look at your web browser. Access to "downloads" is 'File->Downloads`, or something similar. Sketchup and Solidworks also tend to use single word descriptors for menu items.
content.html:
I believe we should leave the menu options in their current location.

My suggestion stems only from what I expect as menu options, and I may not be the best source of info. Take a look at your web browser. Access to "downloads" is 'File->Downloads`, or something similar. Sketchup and Solidworks also tend to use single word descriptors for menu items.

content.raw:
~~~
Topic Visualization
--------------
Oculus Rift
-------------
Show GUI Overlays
Show Toolbars
Fullscreen
(Plot)
~~~

For reference, in the model editor:

~~~
Schematic View
-------------------
Show toolbars
Fullscreen
~~~
content.html:
Topic Visualization
--------------
Oculus Rift
-------------
Show GUI Overlays
Show Toolbars
Fullscreen
(Plot)

For reference, in the model editor:

Schematic View
-------------------
Show toolbars
Fullscreen

content.raw:
I like the brevity of `Edit->Terrain` and the menu name connection to menu option clearly defines what you are doing. To me it is more clear.

I've also never seen the `Open ...` phrase in an application. Except if you are opening a file.

content.raw: I worry that those options are visually so far removed from the Edit menu label that folks might not make the connection that it's Edit--> Model. Just seeing "Model" as an option could be confusing. Since The Building Editor and Model Editor are separate modes within Gazebo, I think it's important to be descriptive and indicate to the user that they're going to open a special mode.
content.html: I worry that those options are visually so far removed from the Edit menu label that folks might not make the connection that it's Edit--> Model. Just seeing "Model" as an option could be confusing. Since The Building Editor and Model Editor are separate modes within Gazebo, I think it's important to be descriptive and indicate to the user that they're going to open a special mode.

content.raw: Yeah that's probably not being used either, since we don't have a status bar on Gazebo. Using [`setToolTip`](http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/qaction.html#toolTip-prop) instead should do what we want here.
content.html: Yeah that's probably not being used either, since we don't have a status bar on Gazebo. Using setToolTip instead should do what we want here.
